desc: Troops advanced several miles along two main lines of attack in Kyiv’s drive to reach the southern coast and sever Russian supply lines, while explosions echoed at the vital Kerch Strait Bridge.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Zelensky Called Him a Criminal. Now Ukraine Calls Him for Guns and Ammo.
desc: In its hunt for weapons, Ukraine has rolled back anticorruption rules and turned to people once seen as relics of an anything-goes era.
author: By Justin Scheck and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: Ukraine Fires Top Military Enlistment Officers After Bribery Scandal
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky said he was removing all 24 regional recruitment chiefs, as corrupt draft evasion schemes put the confidence of the public and Ukraine’s Western backers at risk.
author: By Marc Santora

header: They Endured One Russian Occupation. Now, They Fear a Second.
desc: The torture rooms in the battered Ukrainian city of Kupiansk have been empty for months. But Moscow’s advancing forces are just five miles away.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Emile Ducke

header: She Once Ran Against Putin. Her Advice Now: Resistance Is Futile
desc: Ksenia Sobchak, one of the best known media figures still in Russia, says her fatalistic stance just reflects a grim reality. Some liberals call her a Kremlin stooge, while hawks see her as disloyal.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Listen: Remembering Pee-wee Herman, Rediscover Nina Simone, and the Modern Love Finale
desc: Each week, we share the best of new audio journalism and storytelling.
author: By New York Times Audio

header: A Drone’s View Behind Russian Lines: Cratered Fields and Charred Armor
desc: A Ukrainian unit sent a drone into Russian-occupied territory to surveil the battlefront, and it brought back vivid images of the Russian side of the war zone.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Diego Ibarra Sanchez

header: Heat, War and Trade Protections Raise Uncertainty for Food Prices
desc: Experts are warning of a new normal in which food supplies — and prices — could be rocked more regularly.
author: By Eshe Nelson, Ana Swanson and Jeanna Smialek

header: Explosion Rocks Russian Military Optics Plant Near Moscow
desc: Russian officials said one person was killed and dozens were injured in the blast. The warehouse is on the grounds of a plant that has produced night vision devices and binoculars, according to local news media.
author: By Marc Santora and Valeriya Safronova

header: After Russian Attack in Ukraine, Broken Glass and Rattled Nerves in Romania
desc: A drone assault on a Danube River port sent shock waves — both the physical and the psychological kind — into villages just across the water that are in NATO territory.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: A Missile Strikes the Heart of a Ukrainian City — and Then Another
desc: Ukrainians say the explosions 37 minutes apart in Pokrovsk, which killed at least nine people and injured 82 others, were a “double tap” intended to kill rescuers responding to the first strike.
author: By Gaëlle Girbes and Marc Santora

header: U.K. Sanctions Target Foreign Suppliers for Russia’s Military
desc: New measures announced Tuesday will affect businesses in Turkey, Dubai and Iran, as well as individuals that Britain says have supplied weaponry or components needed to sustain Russia’s war in Ukraine.
author: By Stephen Castle

header: Turbulent Waters: How the Black Sea Became a Hot Spot in the War
desc: The Black Sea, a largely overlooked part of the war in Ukraine, is suddenly a cauldron of military and geopolitical tensions. The region is deeply important to Moscow, Ukraine and the West.
author: By Marc Santora and Steven Erlanger

header: An Oil-Rich Ally Tests Its Relationship With the U.S.
desc: The United Arab Emirates, which has translated its wealth into outsize global influence, is diverging from U.S. foreign policy — particularly when it comes to isolating Russia and limiting ties with China.
author: By Vivian Nereim

header: Ukraine Says Russian Missiles Struck Town of Pokrovsk, Killing 5
desc: The strikes hit the center of the small city in eastern Ukraine twice within 40 minutes, officials said. At least 31 people were injured.
author: By Anushka Patil

header: Russian Strikes Kill Several in Eastern Ukraine
desc: Two Russian missiles hit the center of Pokrovsk, a small city in the Donetsk region. At least five people were killed and at least 31 others were injured, Ukrainian officials said.
author: By The Associated Press

header: ‘It’s Not a Sprint,’ Ukraine’s Marines Insist. ‘It’s a Marathon.’
desc: Journalists from The Times spent two weeks with troops from brigades trained and supplied by NATO to get their take on how, and where, the counteroffensive is going.
author: By Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko and Diego Ibarra Sanchez

header: Ukraine Strikes 2 Bridges Connected to Russian-Occupied Crimea
desc: Ukraine has grown bolder, firing drones at Moscow, while Russian forces have turned to regular attacks on the Black Sea, a crucial economic lifeline.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Vivek Shankar and Anushka Patil

header: Man of the People? Jolted by a Mutiny, Putin Works the Crowds.
desc: His contained interactions with crowds this summer are a noticeable change for the Russian leader, who disdains retail politics and operated in extreme seclusion during the pandemic.
author: By Paul Sonne

header: Battle at Sea Intensifies as Ukraine Drone Hits 2nd Russian Ship in 2 Days
desc: In addition to the strike on an oil tanker, Ukraine issued a warning that commercial ships using any of six Russian Black Sea ports would be considered military targets.
author: By Marc Santora and Christiaan Triebert

header: Anna Netrebko Sues Met Opera After Losing Work Over Support of Putin
desc: Seeking at least $360,000, the singer accused the storied opera house of discrimination, defamation and breach of contract. The company disputed her claims.
author: By Javier C. Hernández

header: Ukraine Hits a Distant Russian Ship, Showing Reach of Naval Drones
desc: The attack damaged the warship hundreds of miles from Ukrainian-held territory, as Kyiv increasingly tries to bring the war home to Russia.
author: By Marc Santora and Christiaan Triebert

header: Ukrainian Maritime Drone Hits Russian Warship
desc: Video released by the Ukrainian military shows a Ukrainian drone attack on a Russian naval ship in the port of Novorossiysk.
author: By Storyful

header: Chris Christie Meets With Ukrainian President in Surprise Trip to Kyiv
desc: Mr. Christie is the second 2024 G.O.P. hopeful to visit the war-torn nation, signaling his support for Ukraine in its effort to repel Russia.
author: By Charles Homans

header: ‘It’s Crazy’: The Scramble for Ancient Treasures After Ukraine’s Dam Disaster
desc: After the Kakhovka dam was blown up in June, the reservoir above it quickly drained, revealing a bonanza of artifacts that has electrified Ukrainian archaeologists.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O’Reilly

header: Conflict Erupts Among Russia’s Pro-War Bloggers
desc: A new tone has set in among the uninhibited military bloggers, whose support for the invasion has given them unusual powers to speak out.
author: By Valeriya Safronova

header: Pastor or Traitor? Ukrainians Shun a Church Seen as a Kremlin Tool.
desc: The village parishioners’ decision to oust their priest reflects a broader push within Ukraine to reduce the influence of an Orthodox church that answers to Moscow.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Yurii Shyvala

header: Ukrainian Troops Trained by the West Stumble in Battle
desc: Ukraine’s army has for now set aside U.S. fighting methods and reverted to tactics it knows best.
author: By Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper

header: As Russia Strikes Ports, Ukraine’s Farmers Scramble to Keep Exporting
desc: Their grain and sunflower oil once helped feed the world. Now, even their backup routes to the international market have become targets.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Putin’s Crackdown Leaves Transgender Russians Bracing for Worse
desc: A new law underscores how Vladimir V. Putin is increasingly using the war in Ukraine as justification for greater restrictions on L.G.B.T.Q. life, portraying it as a consequence of deviant Western values.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Georgy Birger

header: Ukraine’s Attacks in Russia Aimed at Degrading Moscow’s Ability to Wage War
desc: The stepped-up drone and missile attacks show a will to hamper the Kremlin’s military logistics, and to remind ordinary Russians of the cost of war.
author: By Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Ukraine’s Other Counteroffensive: Drone Attacks on Russian Soil
desc: Officials in Ukraine rarely discuss attacks on targets inside Russia, including Moscow. But video evidence shows an increasing effort to launch long-range strikes inside the country.
author: By Christiaan Triebert, Haley Willis, Yelyzaveta Kovtun and Alexander Cardia

header: A Spending Boom Fuels Russia’s Wartime Economy, Raising Bubble Fears
desc: The economic strength has helped to maintain popular support for Vladimir Putin’s war, but some have warned the state-led spending is threatening the country’s financial stability.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Amid the Counterattack’s Deadly Slog, a Glimmer of Success for Ukraine
desc: Recapturing the village of Staromaiorske was such welcome news for the country that President Volodymyr Zelensky announced it himself. But formidable Russian defenses have stymied progress elsewhere.
author: By Carlotta Gall

header: Russia Says 2 Drones Hit Buildings in Moscow in Latest Wave of Attacks
desc: The strike was the third in the past week in Moscow, a sign of how no city in Russia or Ukraine appears to be safe from the war. Russia blamed Ukraine, which has yet to comment.
author: By Andrés R. Martínez and Anton Troianovski

header: Russia Strikes Another Grain Terminal, Extending a Campaign Against Ukraine’s Ports
desc: In St. Petersburg, President Vladimir V. Putin rejected calls for reviving a Black Sea grain deal or for ending fighting.
author: By Marc Santora and Victoria Kim

header: ‘We Can Never Forgive This’: In Odesa, Attacks Stoke Hatred of Russia
desc: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia views Odesa as a culturally important part of his nation. But many in the Ukrainian city reject the connection and view the country that has been attacking it with loathing.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Emile Ducke

header: Ukraine Launches Rare Missile Strikes in Russia, Moscow Says
desc: Kyiv did not take responsibility for the attacks, which could be a bid to broaden a war that has mostly rained ruin and death on Ukraine.
author: By Marc Santora and Anton Troianovski

header: Downed Missile Damages City in Southwestern Russia, Moscow Says
desc: Russian officials said a Ukrainian missile was shot down over the port city of Taganrog and exploded, injuring several people.
author: By The Associated Press

header: Yevgeny Prigozhin: From Putin’s ‘Chef’ to His Biggest Threat
desc: Yevgeny Prigozhin transformed from one of Vladimir Putin’s closest allies to the biggest threat to face the Kremlin in decades. So how did he go from serving dinner to dignitaries to staging a rebellion against the Russian army? New York Times correspondent Valerie Hopkins explains.
author: By Nikolay Nikolov, Ruru Kuo and James Surdam

header: With Slow Advance, Ukraine Aims for Better Shot at Russian Targets
desc: Ukraine is hoping that mile-by-mile gains could bring its weapons closer to Russian supply lines, if its forces can overcome Russia’s heavy defense.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Europe Vowed to Make Russia Pay for the War. It’s Not That Easy.
desc: Confiscating Russian state assets frozen by the United States and Europe could breach international law and set a dangerous precedent, experts say.
author: By Monika Pronczuk and Eshe Nelson

header: They Tried to Rally South America Behind Ukraine. They Nearly Got Killed.
desc: A deadly missile strike on a crowded restaurant wounded three Colombians who hope to build support for Ukraine in a continent that has avoided taking sides.
author: By Gabriela Sá Pessoa

header: Ukraine’s Stepped-Up Assault Grinds Forward, but Scale Is Unclear
desc: Kyiv has intensified its counteroffensive against the Russian invasion, but has kept things murky on the size of the assault, the casualties and what forces it still has in reserve.
author: By Marc Santora and Richard Pérez-Pena

header: Wooing African Nations, Putin Casts West as a Common Foe
desc: At a summit in St. Petersburg, Russia, President Vladimir V. Putin offered free grain as he sought to shore up ties with the continent. But lower-than-hoped-for attendance among African leaders hinted at tempering support.
author: By Anton Troianovski, Declan Walsh and Lynsey Chutel

header: A Ukrainian fencer is disqualified after refusing to shake hands with a Russian opponent.
desc: The 17-month war continues to disrupt competitions a year before the Summer Olympic Games in Paris.
author: By Gabriela Sá Pessoa and Jeré Longman
